Charts & Graphs

Use charts or graphs when users need the ability to analyze, communicate, plan or monitor data. Use the color palettes detailed below to serve their appropriate communication goal: do not use color as a decorative element, but for intentional data display.

Examples

${require('html-loader?interpolate!../../partials/toggles.html')}

We feature 3 common graph types as examples. Other graph types can be created using the provided colors and Chart.js library.

Bar Graph

Pie Chart

Guidelines

  • Visualizations should be used when words or data alone cannot express discovered patterns or trends.
  • Accompany visualizations with a data table to accommodate accessibility guidelines.
  • Whenever possible, provide enough context to show the graphâ€™s purpose without requiring additional explanation or training.
  • Use the provided color palettes. These palettes were created intentionally to provide appropriate contrast ratios to allow users to discern differences and patterns within data sets.
  • Always use the colors in the order they are presented in the palette examples.

Qualitative Palette

The Qualitative Palette is designed to be used in charts and graphs with one or more data series, where each color represents a data series.
Palette Values

#367c2b
RGB (54, 124, 43)

Semantic Palette

The Semantic Palette is designed to communicate good, bad, critical, and neutral values.

Sequential Palette

The Sequential Palette is designed to communicate high and low values for a particular measurement.

Documentation

Javascript

Charts and graphs use the Chart.js library included in UXFrame Plus.
